awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Plant-microbe effects on soil carbon storage in a changing global environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Our planet's environment is changing. Since the Industrial Revolution, land use change, fertilizer use, and fossil fuel combustion have increased atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations by 40% and nitrogen inputs twelve fold. Plants and soils could either mitigate or accelerate this global change because of their role in taking up and cycling carbon and nutrients. This research addresses how one key player in plant-soil systems affects carbon storage and release. Fungi in soil connect to plant roots and transfer nutrients from the soil to the plant in exchange for carbon from the plant. However, it is unclear whether these fungi will facilitate net retention or release of carbon in the soil. On the one hand, fungi could protect carbon in soil under elevated CO2 concentrations. It is also possible that soil fungi have the opposite effect, and accelerate decomposition of carbon. This doctoral dissertation improvement grant project will test the extent to which each of these scenarios is accurate.  Experiments will take place at Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve in Minnesota where the Ph.D. student has conducted her main dissertation research. Results from this research, combined with the student's ongoing work, will inform how total soil carbon storage might be affected by soil fungi in a changing global environment.

This research will not only advance understanding of global change effects on C cycling but will also provide unique educational opportunities. This award will greatly enhance the Ph.D. student's graduate training through collaboration in stable isotope analysis - a novel tool for studying flow of C through ecosystems - which would not be possible otherwise. Through performing the proposed work in collaboration with Dr. Elise Pendall (University of Western Sydney), who has significant experience with stable isotope analysis, the student will develop a strong skill set, building off her participation in the NSF-funded Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry and Ecology course at the University of Utah. Developing skills in using stable isotopes in ecological research could also generally increase the value she would bring to future collaborations. Additionally, the graduate student will leverage her ongoing leadership with the Boreas Environmental Leadership Program at the University of Minnesota's Institute on the Environment to explore new professional development opportunities for graduate students in the sciences to discuss and practice sharing their research to non-academic audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Since the Industrial Revolution, atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentrations have increased by 40% and biologically reactive nitrogen (N) inputs have gone up twelve-fold. Because both CO2 and N are plant resources, the dramatic and ubiquitous change in their availability could influence how plants grow, the flow of carbon (C) to microorganisms in the soil, and the cycling of C in soils (and release back to the atmosphere through decomposition). Ultimately, how plants and soils respond to these environmental changes could result in either mitigating or accelerating the build-up of CO2 in the atmosphere. While decades of experiments have provided insight into how plant growth might respond to elevated CO2 and N deposition, there is still considerable uncertainty around how global change will affect losses of C from soils. And soils are the largest terrestrial pool of carbon (C), so even relatively small changes in soil C stocks could have large implications for atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentrations.

This research sought to assesses the effects of elevated CO2 and N addition on a process that contributes substantially to soil C loss: “rhizosphere priming,” or the effects of roots and their release of soluble carbon, on the rates of decomposition of older soil organic matter by the root-associated microbial communities. When roots release C into the soil it fuels the local microbial community that can lead to their consumption of the recently released root C as well as further decomposition of nearby, older C in soil organic matter. The amount of C lost from rhizosphere priming could change in the future because increasing atmospheric CO2 concentrations and nitrogen (N) deposition could alter plant allocation of C resources belowground, which is the driving force behind the priming process.

We tested the effects of elevated CO2 and N addition on soil C loss and the amount of C specifically lost through the rhizosphere priming mechanism. To do this, we set up a sub-experiment within the Biodiversity, CO2, and Nitrogen Experiment at the Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve in central Minnesota, USA. We harnessed differences in stable isotope chemistry between plants and soil (that we picked because they naturally differ in their isotopic signatures) to partition the amount of total C originating from soil organic matter, and the specific amount decomposed as a result of rhizosphere processes. The research further explored the relationship between a key soil microorganism – arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi – in influencing loss of soil C through priming.

Overall, elevated CO2 increased the soil C loss from rhizosphere priming of decomposition by 39%, and N addition reduced the soil C loss from priming by 29%. Contrary to our expectations, there was no mediation of the elevated CO2-induced rhizosphere priming effect with N addition (i.e. no CO2*N interaction), as we expected if plant nutrient status is a primary driver of the rhizosphere priming CO2 effect. We were also surprised to find a 4-fold difference in the amount of C lost from rhizosphere priming of decomposition between the two cool-season grass species studied (smooth brome, Bromus inermis, and quack grass, Elymus repens). Furthermore, the research suggested that priming could be greater with higher abundance of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, which are further expected to increase their extent under elevated CO2.

Overall, these findings support the hypothesis that increasing concentrations of atmospheric CO2 could result in greater loss of old, soil organic matter-derived C from grassland soils. If these findings hold over longer timeframes and in more diverse plant communities it could facilitate the acceleration of CO2 build-up in the atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit: The project advances understanding of soil C cycling under changing resource availabilities, and the contribution of biological processes, which is especially critical to understanding how soil C stocks may change in the future. Elucidating the effects of plant-microbe-soil interactions on C pools represents a unique contribution to the goal of understanding global change effects on C cycling.

Broader Impacts: The research also greatly enhanced the co-PI’s graduate training by creating the opportunity to develop skills in stable isotope analysis and additional methods in assessing microbial biomass and activity. Through performing the research, and developing collaborations, the co-PI developed a strong skillset, building off her participation in the NSF-funded Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry and Ecology course at the University of Utah. She also published this work as part of her dissertation and presented on it to various audiences.
